subject: Re: [junit] handling test reports
msgSnippet: ... We did this too: one set of fast tests that run always and one set of slow tests that CruiseControl runs. Very effective. ... Absolutely. Don t treat the
messageBody:
>So said Jeff Nielsen on 2003-08-06 --------------------
>If the developers run all of the tests each time they check in (rather than
>waiting for the nightly build), then they know immediately which tests they
>have broken and which they are responsible for fixing. If you have 100
>tests failing on a typical night, something needs to change about the
>process!
>
>Our current project has 1040 "regular" JUnit tests that run in about 10
>seconds. So the developers run all of them all day long after everything
>they do. As soon as one of them breaks, we fix it right away. There are
>another 200 or so tests that take a little longer (some use Catcus on the
>server side, some use database connections). These run automatically when
>anyone checks in (kicked off by Cruise Control) , so within 10 minutes of
>submiting code to the repository, you know whether you have broken any of
>these "integration level" tests.

We did this too: one set of fast tests that run always and one set of slow tests that CruiseControl runs. Very effective.

>Once the norm becomes all of the tests passing (rather than 100 failing),
>the nature of your problem may change. This is a much more scalable
>approach than trying to manage/distribute failure reports.

Absolutely. Don't treat the symptom; treat the problem.

Take care.
